Award.AwardTitle: The Lowell Observatory Navajo-Hopi Astronomy Outreach Program: the Kayenta Unified School District Collaboration
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will fund five partnerships as part of the Lowell Observatory Navajo-Hopi Astronomy Outreach program in the 2018-19 school year. The program, which is in its 23rd year, is beginning a collaboration with 4th-7th grade teachers in the Kayenta Unified School District, located in the Navajo Nation of northern Arizona. Teachers are paired with an astronomer/educator from Lowell Observatory who regularly visits the observatory. Star parties are held in partnership with tribal educators who present traditional knowledge, and students visit Lowell Observatory as a culminating experience.

The curriculum uses Project Based Learning, which education research has shown to be particularly effective with Native children. Topics for the new units are aligned with state, national, and Navajo tribal standards. Curriculum units will be developed, tested, and evaluated, and successful units will be made available free to educators. Navajo and Hopi elders and educators will be involved in this process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018-19 school year was the 23rd year of the Lowell Observatory Navajo-Hopi Astronomy Outreach Program, a science enrichment and training program for 4th-8th grade Native American teachers and their students. The program pairs astronomers with teachers for one year. The astronomer visits the classroom throughout the year, leading astronomy discussions and hands-on activities in collaboration with the teacher. 

This school year we began a 3-year collaboration with the Kayenta Unified School District. We are partnering with 7 teachers (two 4th grade, two 5th grade, two 6th grade, and the one 7th grade) to develop, test, and implement an astronomy-centered curriculum unit for each grade level. The curriculum uses Project Based Learning, is clearly aligned to state (primarily Arizona), Common Core, Next Generation Science, and Din? tribal standards, and includes ties throughout to tribal traditional astronomy and local perspectives. The goal of the curriculum development is to produce hands-on units for our program to share with teachers that enable the students to better see themselves as scientists and science as relevant to their lives.

Lowell?s Master Teacher produced the units in the summer of 2018, each based around a major standard for that grade level. Teachers were asked for input, and our Navajo cultural collaborator contributed cultural connections to add to the units. Each KUSD teacher was paired with an astronomer/educator from Lowell Observatory who visited the classroom throughout the year and collaborated with the teacher in carrying out the curriculum unit. In the Fall, we held training days and at the end of the school year, we held review meetings to improve the units for the next school year.

The 4th grade unit is on wind erosion and compares sand dunes that are currently taking over grazing land on the Navajo Nation with those on Mars. In fact, one student this year mentioned that one of his chores is to remove sand from a nearby growing sand dune at their home. The in-class lab consists of recreating sand dunes with a fan to produce wind so that they could watch the dunes evolve over a few months. The students were given a picture of sand dunes on Mars and asked to explain how those dunes are being shaped and evolving. The technology component of this unit uses Ozobots, simple small robots programmed to follow a course through the sand dunes.

The 5th grade unit is on characteristics of the planets. The students learn about the characteristics of Earth, Mars, and Venus. They recreate key elements of each environment in a bottle that also contains yeast. A balloon sealing the top of the bottle is used to measure the success of life in that environment. The final poster is a travel brochure for either Mars or Venus that explains how they would enable human beings to live on that planet. The technology component is a Sphero robot that is programmed through a tablet to explore a planet surface of their making.

The 6th grade unit is on energy and energy transfer in ecosystems. This focusses on the sun and how the energy that comes to us in the form of sunlight powers living things on Earth. The students also learn about life in extreme environments on Earth and what this might mean to life elsewhere in the solar system. They play a game in the form of a race for survival with students acting as sunlight runners, nature, producers, primary consumers, and secondary consumers. Students learn about the transfer of energy and also about the limiting factors in the cycle. This game is also used to demonstrate what happens if an asteroid impact throws up a lot of dust into the atmosphere interrupting the amount of sunlight getting to Earth, as happened to the dinosaurs. The students then take what they have learned to create an energy cycle under the frozen surface of oceans on Titan and Europa. They use Ozobots to demonstrate the energy map.

The 7th grade unit is on human made and controlled ecosystems in space. Students design and create an ecosystem in a sealed bottle and observe the plants and water levels for 4 weeks. The students then apply what they have learned to the challenges of living in space: how would you fit carbon/nitrogen cycles in a spacecraft and deal with limitations on weight. They follow this with an experiment of growing plants without soil. Students use Ozobots to illustrate how the resource cycles would work on a spacecraft and this is the final product that they share with astronomers at Lowell on their field trip.
